div.div: Wayzata Public Schools will be closed for students through April 30. Online learning will begin for our students on Monday, April 6 following our previously-scheduled spring break. Visit our Coronavirus COVID-19 Response Plan page for more information about Online Learning Plans, Meals for Students in Need, and Childcare for Emergency Personnel. Updated Friday, April 17 at 3:00 p.m.
Register your student for school.

We are committed to excellence! Our students come from eight suburban communities. Our teachers are among the best in the country. And our academic programs are nationally recognized.
Discover more
Teachers and staff at our 14 schools help students discover their unique talents, develop a love and tenacity for learning, and become confident and successful in school and life.

h2.a: Communications

div.p: Wayzata Public Schools will communicate with students, families, staff and community members through the following methods:

ul.li: Email Notifications (English, Somali and Spanish)
Automated and Individual Telephone and Text Messages (English, Somali and Spanish)
Websites: district and school/program sites
Social Media: Facebook, Twitter and Instagram (district and school sites)
Online Learning Platforms: (e.g. Seesaw for Pre-K-grade 3 and Canvas for grades 4-12)
Print Resources
Sharing messages with local media and district key communicators

div.p: If you have questions about distance learning for your child, please contact your student’s teacher(s) first and then your building principal. You can also email communications@wayzataschools.org and your question will be routed to the appropriate staff member who can help.

h2.a: Resources for Support

p.span: Your school social worker is still here to support you and your child! We can be reached by phone or email.

a.title: What Every Elementary/Middle Student Needs to Know about the Coronavirus

p.a: What Every Kid Needs to Know about the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Online Health Seminar
p.br: This one-hour webinar is designed for elementary, middle, and high school children, their parents/guardians, teachers, counselors, school administrators, and anyone who is interested in getting information on the novel coronavirus or COVID-19. The webinar will use medically accurate and age appropriate content for 5-13 year olds. The content will focus on basic facts related to the science and public health along with frequently asked questions about how the coronavirus impacts things that matter to children like their friends, pets, vacations, etc. Webinar log in details will be sent one day before the webinar. Presenter is Dr. Anthony Santella, Associate Professor of Public Health at Hofstra University.

div.p: Contact your school social worker regarding resources for mental health needs.

ul.li: Video for Children - Video explaining coronavirus and common feelings children may experience

District Breakfast and Lunch - Use this link to find the most up to date information about how to obtain weekly meals. These meals are free and available to anyone under the age of 18 years old! Meals are available for pickup at district locations or can be delivered if you can not access the distribution sites.

h2.a: State Emergency Operations Center Assistance Hotline Information

div.p: Below is a hotline that has been created for families to obtain information about childcare resources and other general questions about the school closure. The State Information Hotline at the State Emergency Operations Center (SEOC) will be staffed from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. to answer questions about childcare resources and general questions during the time of school closure.

ul.li: Greater Minnesota: 1-800-657-3504

h2.a: Speaking to Kids about COVID-19

div.p: Several links are included below that may be helpful to parents and students.

h2.a: Childcare for Children of Healthcare and Emergency Personnel

div.p: As part of Governor Walz's emergency executive order, Wayzata Public Schools is providing childcare for healthcare and emergency personnel workers. We are suspending our current childcare program to implement the new guidelines.

The Emergency Childcare Program is operating at Greenwood Elementary School, Monday through Friday from 6:30 a.m. to 6:15 p.m. at no cost to eligible tier 1 families. Childcare is available for students currently enrolled in our school district from all-day preschool participants through grade 5. In order to be in compliance with social distancing recommendations, children in emergency care will be in classrooms/spaces by age groups keeping groups small, and circulating activities into a variety of classrooms/spaces. Transportation services are available upon request.

div.a: Childcare for Emergency Personnel

h2.a: Meals for Students in Need

div.p: Meals for anyone in our district under 18 years old (five breakfast and five lunches per student) will be distributed every Monday while schools are closed.

ul.li: Central Middle School, 305 Vicksburg Lane, Plymouth, 11:30 a.m. - 1:30 p.m.
Vicksburg Commons, 6040 Shenandoah Lane, Plymouth, 10:45-11:15 a.m.
Willow Wood Estates, 10850 South Shore Drive, Plymouth, 11:30 a.m. - 12:00 p.m.
Look for a Wayzata Public Schools truck at distribution sites.
If you do not have transportation, please call 763-745-5154.

We will practice social distancing of 6 feet. At Central Middle School, please follow the signs and stay in your vehicle. Food will be loaded into your trunk. At Vicksburg Commons and Willow Wood Estates, we ask that one to two individuals come and pick up meals.

div.a: Information about Food Distribution

a.title: Información de la Distribución de Comida

div.a: Información de la Distribución de Comida

h2.a: Students Experiencing Homelessness or Housing Instability

div.p: Students experiencing homelessness face unique barriers from school closings and participating in distance learning, including limited availability of technology and living situations, which do not support alternative learning formats. Schools have critical responsibilities for the education of these students, and are critical partners in the community-wide response to addressing the unique vulnerabilities of these students. Students experiencing homelessness are disproportionately students of color, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or queer (LGBTQ), and/or students with disabilities. As such, a robust plan for meeting the needs of these students will help ensure all Minnesota students can equitably participate in distance learning.
To address these challenges, Wayzata Public Schools’ McKinney-Vento liaison and/or school social workers will:

ul.li:
Contact eligible families to conduct a needs assessment related to distance learning.
Assess the living situations and other characteristics for students who are experiencing homelessness to determine where the greatest support is needed for them to fully participate in distance learning.
Provide guidance and/or resources to families experiencing homelessness to ensure they have necessary materials to support community mitigation.
Share resources for food support in communities where families are staying, both in and outside of Wayzata Public Schools.

Monitor participation and engagement of homeless and highly-mobile students in distance learning (e.g., including both attendance and performance) to guide whether additional staff support, engagement or assistance are needed via weekly check-ins.
Develop plans to distribute academic materials to eligible families, where families are located as needed.
Encourage students and/or parents to reach out if their living situation changes and access additional support, which promotes a student’s ability to participate in distance learning.
Maintain regular contact with local public health departments, county or Tribal human services departments and Continuum of Care planning bodies on ongoing or emerging needs.
Connect to resources, which assist students and families experiencing homelessness and housing instability.

Monitor evolving and emerging recommendations specifically pertaining to students experiencing homelessness during the COVID-19 pandemic offered by the National Center on Homeless Education, the National Association for the Education of Homeless Children and Youth and SchoolHouse Connection, as well as other recommendations from local resources.

div.p: Please contact Jennifer Welk, District McKinney-Vento liaison, at 763-745-5044 or Jennifer.Welk@wayzataschools.org if you have any questions.

h2.a: Continued Learning at Home When School is Out
Preventing Coronavirus Incidents

div.p: Prevention is key. The District encourages students, staff members and volunteers to continue the following preventative measures to avoid contracting the coronavirus:

ul.li: Covering your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or into your sleeve, and then throwing the tissue in the trash.

Washing your hands often with soap and water for 20 seconds, especially before eating and after using the bathroom. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Avoid touching your face – especially your eyes, nose and mouth – with unwashed hands.
Stay home when sick, and avoid close contact with people who are sick.

div.p: Our Buildings and Grounds Department has increased the frequency of cleaning practices throughout our schools and buildings. Custodians are focusing on sanitizing and disinfecting frequently-used surfaces such as doorknobs, desks, tables, countertops, drinking fountains, etc.

As of March 12, the Minnesota Department of Health is not recommending school closure. However, MDH is recommending reducing the frequency of large gatherings to mitigate the spread of the virus. We also want to limit visitors into our buildings so our custodial staff can focus on keeping our buildings clean and safe. As a result, the following protocols are being put in place immediately:

ul.li: As long as schools remain open, the following after-school programs will remain open: Wayzata Kids (Home Base), WISHES youth classes, high school and middle school practices, and all other after-school programs.
All evening and weekend school-sponsored activities and events (concerts, PTO/A events, etc.) in all district schools and buildings are canceled through April 6.
All Community Education evening and weekend classes, activities and facility rentals in all district schools and buildings are canceled through April 6.
All field trips and other off-campus learning experiences are canceled through April 6.

h2.a: Monitoring for Coronavirus Incidents

div.p: The Minnesota Department of Health has primary responsibility for the overall monitoring of Minnesota residents who may be exposed to the coronavirus, and MDH will inform the District of steps they expect the District to implement.

p.strong: Stay home when sick, and avoid close contact with people who are sick.

h2.a: For Families

div.a: Parent Distance Learning Resources
Student Distance Learning Resources
K-3 Distance Learning Resources

div.h4: Providing Education During a School Closure
div.p: If the situation occurs that a school or all schools need to be closed due to the threat of the Coronavirus, the District intends to provide instruction to students. This will primarily be accomplished through the use of online learning and District-issued devices, such as iPads.
This will require the full cooperation of students, teachers and parents/guardians to make this instruction meaningful and in compliance with Minnesota statutes.

Students will be marked present in eLearning unless they are reported absent using the Skyward Family Access absence reporting process. Enter your child’s absence in Skyward if he or she is not able to participate in eLearning on each day.
English Learner and Special Education services will continue if Distance Learning goes into effect. Teachers will plan instructional activities that align with student needs.

header.h2: Reporting Absences in Skyward Family Access

div.p: Please report absences in Skyward Family Access when your child is absent. Students will be marked present in eLearning unless they are reported absent using the Skyward Family Access absence reporting process. Absent students are considered unexcused without a report from a parent or guardian.
When you are submitting the attendance request in Skyward Family Access, you must be logged in as a parent, not a student.

a.span: How to report attendance in Skyward Family Access

h2.a: For Staff

div.p: Thanks to each and every one of you for the hard work and dedication you have shown over the past few days as we have prepared to serve our students, families and community by providing emergency day care services, meal service, and a solid plan for distance learning (eLearning).

li.a: Employee Group Reporting Expectations March 18 through 20
Employee Group Reporting Expectations March 23 through 27
Paraprofessional, Secretarial & Wayzata Kids Staff eLearning Responsibilities Beginning March 30
Employee Group Reporting Expectations March 30 through April 3
Important Changes for Paraprofessionals and Wayzata Kids Staff – effective April 6, 2020
Important Changes for Culinary Express Staff – effective April 6, 2020
Important Changes for Paraprofessionals: Week of April 13-17
Important Changes for Paraprofessionals: Week of April 20-24

h2.a: Employee Group Reporting Expectations March 18 through 20

ul.li: E-12 Teaching Staff - All E-12 teaching staff should continue to work on preparing eLearning lessons and all other tasks and responsibilities expected of teaching staff. This work may be done from home or during established building hours, Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20. (Includes ECFE, Preschool, Peer Coaches, Counselors, Deans, Social Workers, Teachers on Special Assignment, Long-Term Reserves, and School Nurses.)

Culinary Express Staff - Culinary staff do not report to work on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20 except for those that have been scheduled by the Director of Culinary Express to work food distribution.

Custodial Staff - Custodians should report during regularly scheduled hours on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20 unless they have submitted the necessary paperwork for underlying health conditions. Elementary and Middle School will cover from 6:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. High School will operate first and second shifts. Please connect with your head custodians to confirm hours.

Health and Media Paraprofessionals - Health and Media paraprofessionals should report for regularly scheduled or modified hours on Wednesday, March 18 for iPad distribution and medicine returns. Health and Media Paraprofessionals would not need to report on Thursday, March 19 or Friday, March 20.
Elementary Office Paraprofessionals should report for regularly scheduled or modified hours on Wednesday, March 18 for iPad Distribution.
Secondary Office Paraprofessionals should report for regularly scheduled hours on Wednesday, March 18. All office paraprofessionals should not report on Thursday, March 19 or Friday, March 20.

Community Education Office Paraprofessionals should report during regularly scheduled hours on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20 unless directed otherwise by the Director of Community Education.

Other Paraprofessionals - Classroom, Instruction, ECFE, Pre-School (Peppermint Fence), Lunch/Recess, Security and all other paraprofessionals do not need to report to work on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20.

Principals and Associate Principals - Report to work during regularly-scheduled hours on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20. Principals working from home should inform the Executive Director of Teaching and Learning.

Secretaries - Twelve and 10-month Secretaries will work regularly scheduled hours on Wednesday, March 18. Staff may begin the process of transitioning to working from home on Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20. Staff must work with their direct supervisors to confirm work expectations. All Building Secretaries should leave a message on the main office phone line regarding the frequency in which messages will be checked and that emails are the preferred method of communication at this time.
Special Education Paraprofessionals - Special Education paras do not need to report to work on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20.

Tech Paras - All building tech paraprofessionals should report on Wednesday, March 18 for regularly-scheduled hours to assist with iPad distribution. (Hours may be modified.) Tech Paras do not need to report to their buildings on Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20. The Director of Technology may assign tasks to be completed at home.

Unaffiliated Staff - Unaffiliated Levels 1-9 should report to work on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20 for regularly-scheduled hours. Staff, under the direction of their supervisors, may begin the process of transitioning to working from home.

li.strong: Wayzata Emergency Childcare previously Wayzata Kids (Home Base/Bright Start)
li.br:
Will be located at Greenwood Elementary following regularly scheduled hours (6:30 a.m. to 6:15 p.m.).
Site Managers should report to work on Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20.
Bright Start Preschool Program Instructors will continue preparing for eLearning Wednesday, March 18, Thursday, March 19 and Friday, March 20 and may work from home.
Wayzata Kids/Home Base Program Instructors, Special Needs Program Instructors, and all Program Assistants will be contacted regarding staffing for Emergency Childcare.

h2.a: Employee Group Reporting Expectations March 23 through 27

ul.li: E-12 Teaching Staff - All E-12 teaching staff should continue to work on preparing Distance Learning lessons and all other tasks and responsibilities expected of teaching staff. This work may be done from home or from school for the week of March 23 through 27. In light of any new developments, teachers may be asked to return to school. (Includes ECFE, Preschool, Peer Coaches, Counselors, Deans, Social Workers, Teachers on Special Assignment, Long-Term Reserves, and School Nurses.) Staff will be expected to continue to engage in work from home. This expectation includes attending meetings (IEP, PLCs, evaluations and regularly-scheduled meetings) remotely during this time period. To reiterate, the purpose of these eight days is to be used to refine existing and create new plans to ensure the delivery of a Distance Learning program that the Governor has said can start no sooner than March 30. Wayzata’s distance learning will formally begin April 6 due to spring break.
Culinary Express Staff - Culinary staff do not report to work the week of March 23 through 27 except for those that have been scheduled by the Director of Culinary Express to work food distribution.

Building Office paras may work from home the week of March 23 through 27.

Will be located at Greenwood Elementary following regularly scheduled hours (6:30 a.m. to 6:15 p.m.).

h2.a: Paraprofessional, Secretarial & Wayzata Kids Staff eLearning Responsibilities Beginning March 30

div.p: Minnesota's Governor has directed school districts to prepare and plan for distance learning. Wayzata leadership and teachers have been working hard to develop multi-tiered plans and supports to provide an excellent distance learning experience for our students. As an integral part of our learning community, we will be working to incorporate the skills and talents of paraprofessionals, secretaries and Wayzata Kids staff into our distance learning plans. We know that your students and the teachers you work with miss you, and we want to make sure we find ways for you to connect!

Please note that the Governor has also directed that all employees be paid during the distance learning time period and has asked for schools to be creative in how we utilize and empower our workforce. Obviously your defined roles and duties will need to be modified in the absence of our students. As you are aware, the circumstances we are navigating are fluid and change daily. This memo outlines guidance and expectations based on our current knowledge of the information coming to us from MDH, MDE and the Governor's office.
div.h4: Here is what you need to know:

ol.li: You will be assigned to a work group with an articulated supervisor(s) and a list of expectations. (See below for position expectations.) Specific assignments will be shared later this week.

Your work may be done at home or at school depending on your assignment. If you report to work, you must punch in and punch out to document your time utilizing True Time like usual. If you work from home, there is no expectation to punch in or out. Your supervisor/building principal will work with you to make this determination.
There will be an expectation to be available and engaged during the regularly scheduled school day.

Starting April 6, if you are unavailable to work with students or to meet the outlined expectations, accumulated leave should be used. For example, if you are sick and cannot complete expectations for the day, then sick, personal or vacation leave should be used. Employees choosing not to work when scheduled will also need to use their accumulated leave time or take unpaid leave. Please be aware that you may not be eligible for unemployment benefits because work is available.
It is against District policy to accept money from parents to tutor or interact with their children during your articulated work day.
Those currently enrolled in health insurance and benefits will remain enrolled barring any separation of employment or other unforeseen circumstances.
If you have any health conditions or if you fall in a vulnerable age bracket, please complete the Underlying Health Conditions form that was sent out last week.
All staff will have expectations around a variety of professional development opportunities. This information will be shared with you at a later date.

The majority of hourly staff will be directed to work in the Wayzata Emergency Childcare Program based upon need and numbers of students served. We will rotate staff in and out of the program to ensure equitable distribution of responsibilities.
At this time, staff will continue to be paid for their regularly scheduled work day.

Expectations for full implementation of your new job description expectations will begin on Monday, April 6. (Staff assigned to assist teachers may not be given specific assignments until April 8. We want to make sure our teachers focus on the implementation of distance learning.)

div.h4: How should I prepare for distance learning?

ol.li: Check your email frequently. This is how you will be notified of your work schedule should you be assigned to Wayzata's Emergency Childcare Program.
Review your work assignment
Connect with your supervisor
If appropriate, check in with your students. (cards, letters, phone calls, etc.)

Please note that technology will not be distributed to paraprofessionals. There should be no expectations for paraprofessionals to complete work that would require the need for technology unless your supervising teacher or building principal specifically reaches out to you with said expectation.

Distance Learning Paraprofessionals - One paraprofessional (K-8) will be assigned to every grade level per building. This person will work with grade-level teams to assist the teacher and provide support to the students. (This includes providing support to that grade-level curriculum and classroom needs. Cleaning manipulatives, preparing curriculum, taking inventory, providing indirect support to students. etc.)
Kindergarten Paraprofessionals - Continue work to support the Kindergarten teacher, students and classrooms. Classroom assignments will remain the same.

Special Education Paraprofessionals providing support in Wayzata Emergency Childcare - Paraprofessionals with specific training will work with special education students attending Wayzata's Emergency Childcare. Also, one paraprofessional will be assigned per group of ten (10) school-aged children. The District Sped Behavior Para will be assigned to Wayzata Emergency Childcare to assist in working with students and training staff.
Early Learning School Assistants/Paraprofessionals - Continue to work to support the early learning school teacher, students and classroom. Classroom assignments will remain the same.
Office Paraprofessionals - Continue to complete attendance functions and expectations similar to expectations during the regular school year. Building principals may assign tasks as necessary.
Media Paraprofessionals - Work with building principals and District staff to prepare media centers for renovations. Building principals may assign tasks as necessary.
Health Paraprofessionals - Work to provide services to students in the Wayzata Kids Emergency Childcare program and continue to plan and prepare for annual health events.
Transition Paraprofessionals - Continue to work and support the teachers and students in the transition program. Assignments will remain the same.
Technology Paraprofessionals - Continue to provide technology support to our staff and students.
Paraprofessionals assigned to the District Office - Work with District Office staff on a daily basis to complete a variety of office tasks. This position requires a confidentiality expectation.

Paraprofessional assigned to Culinary Express (nine month) - Work with the Director of Culinary Express and/or High School Supervisor on a daily basis to complete a variety of tasks supporting the distribution of breakfast and lunch to district students.
Primary Project Paraprofessionals - Will be assigned to Wayzata Kids Emergency Childcare.
Security Staff and Hall Monitors - Will be assigned to Wayzata Kids Emergency Childcare.
Lunch and Recess Monitors - Will be assigned to Wayzata Kids Emergency Childcare.
Building Secretaries - Work under the direct supervision of the building principal.
Ten-month secretaries - Work under the direct supervision of the building principal/director to complete all assigned tasks at home or in the office.
Twelve-month secretaries - Work under the direct supervision of the building principal/director to complete all assigned tasks at home or in the office.
Community Ed Secretary and Office Professionals - Work under the direct supervision of the director to complete all assigned tasks at home or in the office.
Community Ed (Facility) Building Supervisors - Work under the direct supervision of the Facilities Manager to complete all assigned tasks at home or in the buildings, as designated.

Wayzata Kids Program Instructors, Special Needs Program Instructors and Program Assistants - Work under the direct supervision of the Site Managers and Community Ed supervisors to provide support to Wayzata's Emergency Childcare program.
Positions not listed will be assigned to Wayzata's Emergency Childcare program.

div.p: Distance learning paraprofessionals will provide support to the grade-level (elementary) or team (middle) teachers. One distance learning paraprofessional will be assigned to each grade level or team. Supervision, assignment of tasks, and accountability will be provided by said grade level or team.
Distance learning paraprofessionals will be available the same hours as the team of teachers they support. Work may be assigned at home and/or in the classroom.
Supervisor: Building Principal and Classroom Teachers

Assist with modifying materials

Log communications and contacts with students
Share and assist with graphic organizers

Participate in District Professional Development

Technology support hours will be modified to meet the evolving needs of our stakeholders. Supervisor: Wade Phillips

Participate in District professional development.

h2.a: Important Changes for Paraprofessionals and Wayzata Kids Staff – effective April 6, 2020

div.p: The Governor has shared additional expectations for hourly employees as we work to implement distance learning. The following plan will be implemented starting April 6, 2020.
Due to funding parameters, we will be changing the structure of our Emergency Childcare Program to the following:

Wayzata Kids (Home Base) staff will transition to working hours before and after the school day. (Similar to when school was in session.) Staff with daytime hours may continue to be scheduled for those hours. Staff will no longer be scheduled more than their regularly scheduled hours.
div.h4: Distance Learning School Day (approximately 8 a.m. - 2 p.m.)
div.p: On a rotational basis, all paraprofessionals will work their regularly scheduled number of hours in the Wayzata Emergency Childcare program. (Working hours similar to when school was in session.)

ul.li:
Work Expectations for Paraprofessionals: Paraprofessionals will be scheduled to work five (5) days in the Emergency Childcare program from April 6 through April 30.
Some paraprofessionals may be assigned to duties other than childcare, but everyone will be expected to report to work for five (5) days.
Building principals will follow up with specific building assignments prior to April 8. (Some principals may have already shared this information.)
A paraprofessional's work day will reflect the hours worked during their regularly scheduled school day. (Those hours typically worked when school was in session.)
Paraprofessionals will be expected to punch in and punch out when working in the Wayzata Emergency Childcare program.
Currently assigned paraprofessional work expectations will be suspended when assigned to the childcare program. For example, if you were assigned as a distance learning para those responsibilities will be suspended during your assignment to Wayzata Emergency Childcare.

Schedule for Paraprofessionals: Please review the calendar for your scheduled days. This calendar may change. Paraprofessionals are expected to check the calendar daily.
All paraprofessionals are expected to report to work when scheduled.

Schedule for Wayzata Kids: Wayzata Kids staff schedules will be shared via email.
All staff are expected to report to work when scheduled.
All staff will be scheduled to work one week on-site every 3 to 4 weeks.
Staff will no longer be scheduled for additional hours (beyond your MOU).

Childcare: Free childcare is available to paraprofessionals for their school-age children, including ages 4 (if enrolled in a preschool program) to grade 5 – for the five days that they are working the childcare program if needed. Lunch and breakfast are provided at no charge. Registration for Emergency Childcare

Pay and Benefits: All paraprofessionals and Wayzata Kids staff will be paid their regularly-scheduled hours for the month of April. All benefits that are currently in place will continue barring any exceptions or extenuating circumstances.

Use of Leave Time: If a paraprofessional or Wayzata Kids staff can not work their scheduled hours, they must use their accumulated leave.
Paraprofessionals must report absences into True Time and alert Human Resources. Please email or call Leslie Myrin at 763-745-5016 or Leslie.Myrin@wayzataschools.org.
Paraprofessionals not reporting to work will be rescheduled for the following week.
Paraprofessionals will continue to be rescheduled until distance learning ends and school resumes.
Accumulated leave includes personal, sick, or/and vacation days.
If all accumulated leave is exhausted, then unpaid leave will be used.
Unpaid leave may impact out-of-pocket insurance costs.

Underlying Health Conditions: If paraprofessionals or Wayzata Kids staff have completed the Underlying Health Conditions form, they will be expected to complete work expectations from home. Starting April 1, new requests for underlying health accommodations will require a doctor's note.

div.h4: Paraprofessionals for the week of April 6 - 10

ol.li:
Scheduled paraprofessionals will be expected to report to work following the established calendar.
All employees working in the Wayzata Emergency Childcare program are considered essential employees and are allowed to report to work during the time period of the Governor's shelter in place directive. Please remember your ID/security badge.
Paraprofessionals not scheduled to report to work will be expected to complete professional development equal to their regularly scheduled work week. (If a para works 25 hours when school is in session, the expectation would be to complete 25 hours of professional development.)
Additional information will be emailed later this week.
PD hours should be completed by 5 p.m. on April 10.
Paraprofessionals assigned to other work from home tasks must complete this form, documenting their hours.

div.h4: Wayzata Kids for the week of April 6 - 10

ol.li: Scheduled Wayzata Kids staff will be expected to report to work per the schedule emailed to them. All employees working in the Emergency Childcare program are considered essential employees and are allowed to report to work during the time period of the Governor's shelter in place directive. Please remember your ID/security badge.
Wayzata Kids staff not scheduled to report to work will be expected to complete online learning. Additional details will be emailed to you.
Wayzata Kids staff assigned to work at home or completing professional development are expected to log your hours by 5 p.m. on April 10.
Wayzata Kids staff assigned other work from home tasks must complete this form documenting their hours.

div.p: We care about your safety. Paraprofessionals and Wayzata Kids staff have an extremely important task and we appreciate everything that you are doing to support children during this crisis. It is so important for all of us to support each other, take care of ourselves and work together. Please see below for staff safety precautions.

ol.li: All children and staff will be assessed by our LSNs and health paras every day.
Make sure to wash your hands frequently, cover your cough, and refrain from touching your face. These are the best defenses against the spread of COVID-19.
Please do not report to work if you are exhibiting any of the following symptoms. When to stay home.
Remember your Vital Life Employee Assistance Program is here to support you. User ID is: wayzata Password: member

In order to remain in compliance with our Governor's expectations, we will be implementing a process in which staff will be expected to return to work.

As the District's Culinary Express team, you are tasked with the job of ensuring our children still have access to nutritious breakfasts and lunches. Your contributions are extremely important and words cannot express how much your efforts are appreciated. Please know that we recognize the sacrifices you are making and encourage you to do everything you can to take care of yourself.

Unaffiliated Staff - Unaffiliated Levels 1-9 are expected to work from home.

Wayzata Emergency Childcare - Wayzata Kids staff will continue the rotation schedule currently in place. Please check your email from April 8 for your specific schedule for the week of April 13-17.
Wayzata Kids Site Managers should follow the direction of their supervisor for working on site and at home the week of April 13-17.
Bright Start Preschool Program Instructors will continue eLearning expectations.
Wayzata Kids/Home Base Program Instructors, Special Needs Program Instructors and all Program Assistants that are not scheduled to work onsite at Emergency Childcare will continue professional development opportunities from home.

div.p: Thanks again for your hard work and all the wonderful contributions you are making at this time!

h2.a: Important Changes for Paraprofessionals: Week of April 13-17

div.p: The Governor has extended the stay at home directive until May 4, 2020. Only paraprofessionals assigned to the Emergency Childcare Program will be expected to report to work. The following plan will be implemented starting April 13 through April 17.

Paraprofessionals working from home: All paraprofessionals, unless assigned to the Emergency Childcare Program, should continue to work on the professional development sent to all paraprofessionals on April 6.

ul.li: Full-time employees should complete 20-25 hours of professional development.
Part-time employees should complete their regularly scheduled number of hours.
Work hours may be flexible, but hours for the week should be completed by 5 p.m. on April 17. (It is fine to complete this work outside your regularly-scheduled day.)

Building Principals or Special Education administrators may assign different professional development or tasks to be completed from home. Remember to document time spent on those assignments on this form.

div.p: Work Expectations for Paraprofessionals Assigned to Emergency Childcare: Paraprofessionals will be scheduled to work five (5) days in the Emergency Childcare program for the remainder of the month.

ul.li: A paraprofessional’s work day will be from 8 a.m.- 2 p.m.
Paraprofessionals will be expected to punch in and punch out when working in the Wayzata Emergency Childcare program.

Currently assigned paraprofessional work expectations will be suspended when assigned to the childcare program. For example, if you were assigned as a distance learning para those responsibilities will be suspended during your assignment to Wayzata Emergency Childcare.

Schedule for Paraprofessionals: Please review the calendar for your scheduled days. This calendar may change. Paraprofessionals are expected to check the calendar daily.
All paraprofessionals are expected to report to work when scheduled.
Important: Additional Emergency Childcare Information.

Childcare: Free childcare is available to paraprofessionals for their school-age children, including ages 4 (if enrolled in the Bright Start preschool program) to grade 5 – for the five days they are working the childcare program, if needed. Lunch and breakfast are provided at no charge. Registration for Emergency Childcare

Use of Leave Time: If a paraprofessional can not work their scheduled hours, they must use their accumulated leave.
Paraprofessionals must report absences into True Time and alert Human Resources. Please email or call Leslie Myrin at 763-745-5016 or Leslie.Myrin@wayzataschools.org.
Paraprofessionals not reporting to work will be rescheduled for the following week.
Paraprofessionals will continue to be rescheduled until distance learning ends and school resumes.
Accumulated leave includes personal, sick, or/and vacation days and up to twenty (20) days may be used for refusing to report to work.
If all accumulated leave is exhausted, then unpaid leave will be used.
Unpaid leave may impact out-of-pocket insurance costs.

li.strong: Paraprofessional Expectations for Interacting with Students:

ul.li:
Teachers must be present when paraprofessionals are expected to interact with students utilizing any school-sponsored platform.
Paras may provide positive comments via the SeeSaw and Canvas platforms.
Paras may work alongside the teacher.
Paras may record a read aloud that can be uploaded to a platform.
Paras may make check in phone calls at the direction of the teacher.
Paras may utilize the mail to send notes of encouragement to students.
As a reminder, technology has not been assigned to our paraprofessionals during this time period.

Staff Safety: We care about your safety. Paraprofessionals and Wayzata Kids staff have an extremely important task and we appreciate everything that you are doing to support children during this crisis. It is so important for all of us to support each other, take care of ourselves and work together. Please see below for staff safety precautions.
All children and staff will be assessed by our LSNs and health paras every day.
Make sure to wash your hands frequently, cover your cough, and refrain from touching your face. These are the best defenses against the spread of COVID-19.
Please do not report to work if you are exhibiting any of the following symptoms. When to stay home.
Remember your Vital Life Employee Assistance Program is here to support you. User ID is: wayzata Password: member
The CDC and MDH have shared new guidance in regards to wearing masks. Staff members working in child care programs are encouraged to wear cloth face coverings during the work day as much as possible. This is optional, and not a requirement. Please click here for further information.

div.p: Underlying Health Conditions: If paraprofessionals or Wayzata Kids staff have completed the Underlying Health Conditions form, they will be expected to complete work expectations from home. Starting April 1, new requests for underlying health accommodations will require a doctor’s note.

h2.a: Important Changes for Paraprofessionals: Week of April 20-24

div.p: All paraprofessionals, unless assigned to the Emergency Childcare Program, should continue to work on the professional development sent on April 6. If you have completed those modules, please see “New Professional Development Opportunities” below.

ul.li: Full-time employees should complete 20-25 hours of professional development.
Part-time employees should complete their regularly scheduled number of hours.
Work hours may be flexible, but hours for the week should be completed by 5 p.m. on April 24. (It is fine to complete this work outside your regularly-scheduled day.)
Remember to document time spent on professional development work on this form.

Teaching and Learning has compiled the following professional development opportunities for paraprofessionals. Paras can select offerings, watch or listen to the sessions, and respond using a brief standard reflection form.
Special Services has provided the following training opportunities for professional development.
Sign up to participate in a two-week equity Book Study session. See the Teaching and Learning professional development link (above) in order to register.
Paras working with students with challenging behaviors, and skill building to increase independence. Registered Behavior Technician
40 hours online (free) - certificate of completion (all paras do the training)
Test at the end of the training is not needed.
Module: active responding throughout the training
Coming soon! Insights Discovery Training!

ul.li: Minnesota Online Teacher's Network - MDE is pleased to announce that there is a site up and running with details on practitioner-led professional conversations to support schools and districts transition to distance learning.

hr.p: The District wants you to be aware of the following:

ol.li:
The District will be sharing a process in which employees may borrow sick leave days. In an effort to slow down the spread of coronavirus, we do not want employees coming to work sick due to financial obligations.
Request for Borrowed Sick Days

Wayzata Public Schools has a solid health insurance plan with PreferredOne and will offer the same coverage for COVID-19 testing and care as it does for all other qualified medical expenses. Any in-network costs for this testing and treatment would go toward the annual deductible and out of pocket costs for individuals covered on our health plan. For those employees with a VEBA/HRA or medical flexible spending account, any qualifying COVID-19 expenses would be eligible for reimbursement. We continue to work with our partners to monitor the situation and will communicate any changes.

If an employee is placed on quarantine, due to coronavirus exposure, the employee will be placed on paid leave.
The employee may be asked to work from home.
The employee may be expected to make up those days at a future date without additional pay.
If you have a special health consideration that you are concerned about, please reach out to Human Resources. We want to support your health and well-being.

hr.p: With Spring Break quickly approaching, the District is asking that you carefully consider your travel plans. More information will be shared with you as we get closer to break.
All employees should work to create short-term and long-term plans for their families. Changes to our work days, e-Learning and school closures, may occur on relatively short notice.
The following link is set up for you to share concerns or to get answers to questions you may still have. We will work diligently to respond to your concerns.

article.h2: Wayzata Public Schools will be Closed through April 30

div.p: Dear WPS Families and Staff,

On Wednesday, March 25, 2020, Governor Walz issued an executive order that directs all Minnesotans to stay at home and limit movement out of their homes beyond essential needs effective Friday, March 27 at 11:59 p.m. to Friday, April 10. This two-week, stay-at-home order is to be followed by an additional three weeks of social distancing. Click here for more information about the Governor’s order.

I’m writing to provide information about how the new order affects Wayzata Public Schools. Based on the new order, distance learning has been extended through April 30, 2020. Online learning will begin for our students on Monday, April 6 following our previously-scheduled spring break.

Governor Walz has indicated that at this time the intent is for school staff to return to work on Friday, May 1 and Monday, May 4 in order to prepare for students to return to school on Tuesday, May 5. The Governor stressed that this plan is subject for re-evaluation based on what happens with the evolving coronavirus situation.
div.h4: Food Distribution Continues for Students in Need
div.p: We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch meals for anyone in our district under 18 years old. Please visit our website for more information about food distribution.
Childcare for children of healthcare and emergency personnel will also continue while schools are closed. Visit our website for more information.

Thank you for your continued patience and support as we navigate this challenging situation. We will continue to stay in touch with additional information as it becomes available. Remember that we are here for you and we will get through this together.
Take care of yourself and take care of each other,

Chace B. Anderson
Superintendent
